text: Do we have any data how many people were rejected from giving a JuliaCon talk/BoF/... last year? Do we have any data bow this affected non-male presenters?

Though most people who were rejected were invited to submit posters.
And we can't differentiate people who originally submitted talks and we're offered posters from people who originally wanted posters.

text:
Basically.
It was double blinded during review.
Though it was unblinded during final selection.
Final selection in 2020 was done by Chris R, Renee Spear, and myself.
The final selection being where we determine what is the cut-off review score and make the call for things that are borderline.

This unblinded final selection is useful to catch things.
For example in 2018 by review alone
Jeff Bezanson’s talk “What is wrong with Julia” would have been rejected as the reviewers commented:
“Seems unlikely that the author of this talk is familar enough with how julia was designed and why to really comment well on this”.


But even ignoring the unblinded final selection, the blinded reviews also could have subtle bias.
For example people might be being put off by a way of writing that is indicative of a particular demographic.
